comments.commentBody:
The purpose of a religion is to help give structure to the randomness of chance, and comfort to those on the wrong side of it - in other words, to help human beings cope with the 'slings and arrows of outrageous fortune.'

A church that dictates limitations on how it can accomplish that mission won't survive, simply because it will not be able to help those who need it most.
I say..............prove it!
first horse to do what he did without any bandages on his legs.
Yes yes yes.
You tell 'em, AngelaM! Though I am curious to know whether the employed mothers who were less stressed had full-time help.

*Is* it as we see fit? For some, yes, for others, who else will take care of the children? Daddy dreams of pitching a ball to his kid, playing donkey-on-the-back, and glaring protectively at his daughter's first date. And counts that all as being a good Dad. Throw in some 'babysitting' times when he changes diapers, and he's a hero Dad.

With a partner like that, someone has to do the day to day, minute to minute nurturing work. And expectations it's Mom who does that. No hero Mom - if she does less than the bulk of the work, she's a bad Mom.

So the choice is one from diminished options for many, many women. For some women, of course it is their most desired option and truly freely chosen and it works for their family. And that's fine. But when a survey like this is taken, the others, the expected-to SAH mothers, the single mothers, and the married might-as-well-be-single mothers, will be answering the questions too.

I've done both, and would categorically recommend working if at all possible. Do not give up a career to stay home. If you do stay home, remain active in a career, even if it's attending conferencing, consulting, or freelancing  (scouts, PTA, volunteering are extracurriculars and not your career).

Wow, imagine the howling from the right at employed moms if the results had gone the other way.

"Oh, you have to stay home for the sake of sparing your children from your depression." "You're such a selfish witch for working outside the home. Think of your children." "You see? It's *unnatural* for mothers (even childless/childfree women) to work outside the home. Nature and God intended women to use their uteruses and then become June Cleaver stay-at-home mommies for the rest of their lives."

And btw: What are the results for at-home vs. employed dads vs. employed men with no kids? No one asked them? How strange ...

I don't see any point whatsoever in this study beyond justifying somone's tenure, and occupying graduate students. There's so much more to control for than this article suggests.

Earned income tends to have major implications in the power structures at home, and taking care of small children 24/7 (being entirely responsible for another creature's well-being), even when experienced pleasantly, is a big energy drain. Not to overlook the hassle, expense, and torn emotions involved with daycare, but mothers who work spend more time in the role of "themselves" as an entity apart from their families (hopefully they don't have the job or boss from hell).

Anyway, we're only into the first full generation of a massive modern cultural shift. Before the agricultural and industrial revolutions and the birth of the merchant class, there was no such thing as "stay at home moms" as we came to know it. There were the aristocracy, and everyone else worked every waking hour to survive.

If anything, there's still fallout from the "have it all" mantra crammed down everyone's throat in the 70s and 80s, which set some unknown state as a benchmark for women to measure themselves against. Enough!

Dear New York Times:
Could you please write a story about Stay-at-Home Fathers vs. Employed Fathers? Who's happier? For once, let's start the Daddy Wars. The Mommy Wars have become like beating a dead mare. Enough already.
Why is it so surprising that women who are involved in the wider world are happier?  Why is it so surprising that women who get to engage with adults feel more positive emotions?

I am currently home with two kids under 4 - and my day SO does NOT resemble what you describe.  I am exhausted and I can't even think when I last managed a nap.  Where are the kids while you do that?  A bit of shopping... + all the cooking and cleaning and reading books and trying to balance two kids that are always crying at the same time.... you are living in an alternate world!  How do I get to that world?!

I currently stay at home with my 9- month-old and it is as you describe. I nap when he naps, cleaning isn't like a huge time consuming thing because we live in a small apartment
, we go to the library and the park, I have dinner on the table for husband (he is effusive in his appreciation) and I go to sleep satisfied. I feel like it would be tougher if I had several children, so we've decided to stop at one!
Sounds boring. I have higher ambitions than walking to the park, chatting it up with other moms, and taking naps. If that's all you want to do, go for it!

Worked for 10 years stayed at home for 6 and worked again for another 8.

I can tell you staying at home was BY FAR the best time of my entire life. I loved it. Breast feeding and bliss. Complete joy. My day would be doing a bit of shopping. Walking to the park. Watching the children play while chatting with the other moms. Coming home and having a nap, then making some dinner - and getting pretty for hubby.

Beat that!~

I wonder about this sometimes - especially since I think they don't include cell phones in the study.  So, the only people even eligible to be surveyed are people with landlines.  I can only think of one person my age with kids who has a landline at all!

There are inaccuracies also for any study that involves self-reported data. I'm not sure how else to measure happiness, though.

I take this blog entry for what it is, and interesting report. We can at the least say that the respondents did not report sheer serenity at being fulfilled in their womanly roles.

Slate just did an interesting article on the inherent inaccuracies of telephone surveys. According to the article, only 9% of Americans are willing to participate. So surveys like this Gallup poll are, at best, an indication of the values, preferences, etc. of that 9% of the population. Anyway, here's a link if you're interested: http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2012/05/survey_...

"Do you have thoughts on other ways to investigate how inequality affects mobility within the United States?"

Yes, I have some wicked randomized experiments in mind, but none of them are legal.

Filed under "Q" for "Questions Social Scientists Could Answer if it Weren't for those Pesky Ethics Boards"
By "average New Yorker" do you mean the median?  Where dollars are involved the average is usually around the 75th to 80th percentile, it seems.

Mike, The Gini index itself is a measure of inequality, not the change in Gini index.  Wouldn't you expect higher mobility, on the margin, to result in a reduction of inequality over time?  I think that is what you are picking up in your plots.  I think you have cause and effect reversed.

"Once Romney wins (and the Republicans win the entire legislature) idiotic ideas like this will end up in the "trash heap of history""

LOL...you can dream...but it's only that. Bush was president when the recession started don't forget that. It was precisely republican policies of non-regulation and eliminating Glass-Steagall that led to this recession.
When the neighborhood goes down, people move. Who will support the  deadbeats when there is no rich, not the declining middle class.

Thank you for noticing, Howie. I must've been in a foul mood that day and should've known better. At least others in our fine communal burrow recognize it and stay away on days liked that. I'll know better the next time.

It was a heartfelt and sincere apology, and extended to every member of our coterie.

@Laszlo,

Let's call this water under the bridge. I appreciated the apology. See you down the road.

Laszlo, I feel it was very admirable of you to issue a mea culpa to XwordJ, and I'm fairly certain that others here in WP have taken notice of it.
As I've said in the recent past, you're a most welcome addition to WP with your conspicuous eclat in many fields of knowledge.

Good show, Laszlo!

WHH
I don't think she has to worry too much. She just graduated from med school a few days ago. Not like she won't have a career.
Why would they need a pre-nup? In a worst-case scenario either of 'em will end up billionaires. I wouldn't know what to do with a billion dollars, much less several of them.
I hope this merger will result in some spinoff subsidiaries soon.
So happy for them! What a lovely couple! Congrats! Best wishes, Mark and Priscilla!

Only if that's what the prenup sez, methinks.

In either case, they'll both have had better counsel about CA law and what courts end up deeming “fair” than you or I give.
Regardless of whether Zuckerberg got married today or two weeks ago, his stake in Facebook is separate property, not community property.

Getting married after the IPO is a clever way to protect Facebook assets in the event of a divorce; since they achieved their current value before they tied the knot, she can only hit him for the difference. (California is a community property state).
Well said.  Ditto.  :)
